title: 1877-C
statement: C. Joyboardtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputChaneka, a gamer kid, invented a new gaming controller called joyboard. Interestingly, the joyboard she invented can only be used to play one game.The joyboard has a screen containing $$$n+1$$$ slots numbered from $$$1$$$ to $$$n+1$$$ from left to right. The $$$n+1$$$ slots are going to be filled with an array of non-negative integers $$$[a_1,a_2,a_3,\\ldots,a_{n+1}]$$$. Chaneka, as the player, must assign $$$a_{n+1}$$$ with an integer between $$$0$$$ and $$$m$$$ inclusive. Then, for each $$$i$$$ from $$$n$$$ to $$$1$$$, the value of $$$a_i$$$ will be equal to theremainderof dividing $$$a_{i+1}$$$ (the adjacent value to the right) by $$$i$$$. In other words, $$$a_i = a_{i + 1} \\bmod i$$$.Chaneka wants it such that after every slot is assigned with an integer, there are exactly $$$k$$$ distinct values in the entire screen (among all $$$n+1$$$ slots). How many valid ways are there for assigning a non-negative integer into slot $$$n+1$$$?InputEach test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains an integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\leq t \\leq 2\\cdot10^4$$$) — the number of test cases. The following lines contain the description of each test case.The only line of each test case contains three integers $$$n$$$, $$$m$$$, and $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\leq n \\leq 10^9$$$; $$$0 \\leq m \\leq 10^9$$$; $$$1 \\leq k \\leq n+1$$$) — there are $$$n+1$$$ slots, the integer assigned in slot $$$n+1$$$ must not be bigger than $$$m$$$, and there should be exactly $$$k$$$ distinct values.OutputFor each test case, output a line containing an integer representing the number of valid ways for assigning a non-negative integer into slot $$$n+1$$$.ExampleInput44 6 32 0 1265 265 2653 10 2Output2 1 0 5NoteIn the first test case, one of the $$$2$$$ possible ways for Chaneka is to choose $$$a_{n+1}=6$$$. If she does that, then:$$$a_4=a_5\\bmod 4=6\\bmod 4=2$$$$$$a_3=a_4\\bmod 3=2\\bmod 3=2$$$$$$a_2=a_3\\bmod 2=2\\bmod 2=0$$$$$$a_1=a_2\\bmod 1=0\\bmod 1=0$$$$$$a = [0, 0, 2, 2, 6]$$$There are $$$3$$$ distinct values.In the second test case, the $$$1$$$ possible way for Chaneka is to choose $$$a_{n+1}=0$$$. If she does that, then $$$a = [0, 0, 0]$$$. There is only $$$1$$$ distinct value.In the third test case, there is no possible way for assigning a non-negative integer into slot $$$n+1$$$.

processed.result:
You are given an array of $n+1$ slots, numbered from 1 to $n+1$.  The last slot ($n+1$) can be filled with any non-negative integer between 0 and $m$ inclusive.  The value in each of the other slots is determined by the following rule:

*  $a_i = a_{i+1} \mod i$ 

where $a_i$ is the value in slot $i$, and $a_{i+1}$ is the value in the slot to its right.

You want to find the number of ways to fill the last slot ($n+1$) so that there are exactly $k$ distinct values in the entire array. 



Input:

* $t$ - the number of test cases
* For each test case:
    * $n$ - the number of slots (excluding the last one)
    * $m$ - the maximum value that can be placed in the last slot
    * $k$ - the desired number of distinct values in the array

Output:

* For each test case, output the number of valid ways to fill the last slot.

You have a sequence of slots. The last slot can be filled with a number between 0 and a given limit.  Each slot before the last is filled with the remainder when the number in the slot to its right is divided by its own index.  

You need to find how many different numbers can be placed in the last slot so that there are a specific number of unique values in the entire sequence.
